AutoCarver
  • AutoCarver
  • View page source

AutoCarverÔÉÅ

The core of AutoCarver consists of the following Data Optimization steps:

  1. Identifying the most associated combination from all ordered combinations of modalities.

  2. Testing all combinations of NaNs grouped to one of those modalities.

AutoCarver optimizes association with the two following target types:

  • Binary target for classification models

  • Continuous target for regression models

Binary target for classification modelsÔÉÅ

In AutoCarver a binary target consists of a column \(y\) that only contains \(0\) and \(1\) (no str).

At the basis of AutoCarver‚Äôs‚Äô built-in association measures lays pandas.crosstab. It is computed only once per feature \(x\) against the binary target \(y\). The crosstab between \(y\) and each possible combination of modalities of \(x\) is then obtained via a vectorized, numpy.add. powered, implementation of pandas.groupby.

AutoCarver takes advantage of scipy.stats.chi2_contingency to perform association measuring. It gives Pearson‚Äôs \(\chi^2\) statistics computed from crosstabs.

Cram√©r‚Äôs \(V\) can then be computed using \(V=\sqrt{\frac{\chi^2}{n}}\) where \(n\) is the number of observation. This implementation has been simplified taking into account the binary target \(y\) to improve performances.

Finally, Tschuprow‚Äôs \(T\) is computed using \(T=\frac{V}{\sqrt{\sqrt{n_x-1}}}\) where \(n_x\) is the per-combination number of modalities.

For two combinations of modalities of \(x\), a higher \(T\) or \(V\) value indicates a stronger relationship with the binary target \(y\).

Note

  • Make sure to set AutoCarver.sort_by in ["tschuprowt", "cramerv"] to use AutoCarver for binary targets.

  • For more details, see Pearson‚Äôs \chi^2 test statistic, Cram√©r‚Äôs V and Tschuprow‚Äôs T.

AutoCarver, the automated, fast-paced data processing pipelineÔÉÅ

class AutoCarver.BinaryCarver(min_freq: float, sort_by: str, *, quantitative_features: list[str] | None = None, qualitative_features: list[str] | None = None, ordinal_features: list[str] | None = None, values_orders: dict[str, AutoCarver.discretizers.utils.grouped_list.GroupedList] | None = None, max_n_mod: int = 5, output_dtype: str = 'float', dropna: bool = True, copy: bool = False, verbose: bool = False, pretty_print: bool = False, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

Automatic carving of continuous, discrete, categorical and ordinal features that maximizes association with a binary or continuous target.

First fits a Discretizer, a complete discretization pipeline. Raw data should be provided as input (not a result of Discretizer.transform()).

Initiates a BinaryCarver.

Parameters:

  • min_freq (float) ‚Äì

    Minimum frequency per grouped modalities.

    • Features whose most frequent modality is less frequent than min_freq will not be carved.

    • Sets the number of quantiles in which to discretize the continuous features.

    • Sets the minimum frequency of a quantitative feature‚Äôs modality.

    Tip: should be set between 0.02 (slower, preciser, less robust) and 0.05 (faster, more robust)

  • sort_by (str) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["tschuprowt", "cramerv", "kruskal"] Metric to be used to perform association measure between features and target.

    • Binary target: use "tschuprowt", for Tschuprow‚Äôs T.

    • Binary target: use "cramerv", for Cram√©r‚Äôs V.

    • Continuous target: use "kruskal", for Kruskal-Wallis‚Äô H test statistic.

    Tip: use "tschuprowt" for more robust, or less output modalities, use "cramerv" for more output modalities.

  • quantitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of quantitative features (continuous and discrete) to be carved, by default None

  • qualitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of qualitative features (non-ordinal) to be carved, by default None

  • ordinal_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of ordinal features to be carved. For those features a list of values has to be provided in the values_orders dict, by default None

  • values_orders (dict[str, GroupedList], optional) ‚Äì Dict of feature‚Äôs column names and there associated ordering. If lists are passed, a GroupedList will automatically be initiated, by default None

  • max_n_mod (int, optional) ‚Äì

    Maximum number of modality per feature, by default 5

    All combinations of modalities for groups of modalities of sizes from 1 to max_n_mod will be tested. The combination with the greatest association (as defined by sort_by) will be the selected one.

    Tip: should be set between 4 (faster, more robust) and 7 (slower, preciser, less robust)

  • output_dtype (str, optional) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["float", "str"], by default "float"

    • "float", grouped modalities will be converted to there corresponding floating rank.

    • "str", a per-group modality will be set for all the modalities of a group.

  • dropna (bool, optional) ‚Äì

    • True, AutoCarver will try to group numpy.nan with other modalities.

    • False, AutoCarver all non-numpy.nan will be grouped, by default True

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, feature processing at transform is applied to a copy of the provided DataFrame, by default False

  • verbose (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, prints raw Discretizers Fit and Transform steps, as long as information on AutoCarver‚Äôs processing and tables of target rates and frequencies for X, by default False

  • pretty_print (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, adds to the verbose some HTML tables of target rates and frequencies for X and, if provided, X_dev. Overrides the value of verbose, by default False

  • **kwargs ‚Äì Pass values for str_default``and ``str_nan of Discretizer (default string values).

Examples

See AutoCarver examples

fit(X: DataFrame, y: Series, *, X_dev: DataFrame | None = None, y_dev: Series | None = None) → NoneÔÉÅ

Finds the combination of modalities of X that provides the best association with y.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) ‚Äì Dataset used to discretize. Needs to have columns has specified in AutoCarver.features.

  • y (Series) ‚Äì Binary target feature with wich the association is maximized.

  • X_dev (DataFrame, optional) ‚Äì Dataset to evalute the robustness of discretization, by default None It should have the same distribution as X.

  • y_dev (Series, optional) ‚Äì Binary target feature with wich the robustness of discretization is evaluated, by default None

fit_transform(X, y=None, **fit_params)ÔÉÅ

Fit to data, then transform it.

Fits transformer to X and y with optional parameters fit_params and returns a transformed version of X.

Parameters:

  • X (array-like of shape (n_samples, n_features)) ‚Äì Input samples.

  • y (array-like of shape (n_samples,) or (n_samples, n_outputs), default=None) ‚Äì Target values (None for unsupervised transformations).

  • **fit_params (dict) ‚Äì Additional fit parameters.

Returns:

X_new ‚Äì Transformed array.

Return type:

ndarray array of shape (n_samples, n_features_new)

transform(X: DataFrame, y: Series = None) → DataFrameÔÉÅ

Applies discretization to a DataFrame‚Äôs columns.

  • For each feature‚Äôs modality, the associated group label is attributed as definid by values_orders.

  • If output_dtype="float", converts labels into floats.

  • Data types are matched as input_dtypes=="str" for qualitative features and input_dtypes=="float" for quantitative ones.

  • If copye=True, the input DataFrame will be copied.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) ‚Äì Contains columns named after BaseDiscretizer.features attribute, by default None

  • y (Series, optional) ‚Äì Model target, by default None

Returns:

Discretized X.

Return type:

DataFrame

AutoCarver.BinaryCarver.summary(self) → DataFrameÔÉÅ

Summarizes the data discretization process.

Returns:

A summary of features‚Äô values per modalities.

Return type:

DataFrame

Continuous target for regression modelsÔÉÅ

In AutoCarver a continuous target consists of a column \(y\) that contains values from \(-\inf\) to \(+\inf\) (no str).

The association with a categorical/ordinal feature \(x\) is computed using scipy.stats.kruskal.

Kruskal-Wallis‚Äô \(H\) test statistic, as known as one-way ANOVA on ranks, allows one to check that two samples originate from the same distribution. It is used to determine whether or not \(y\) is distributed the same when \(x=0, ..., x=n_x\), where \(n_x\) is the number of modalities taken by \(x\).

For two combinations of modalities of \(x\), a higher \(H\) value indicates that there is a greater difference between the medians of the samples.

Note

  • Make sure to set AutoCarver.sort_by="kruskal" to use AutoCarver for continuous targets.

  • For more details, see Kruskal-Wallis‚Äô H test statistic.

AutoCarver, the automated, fast-paced data processing pipelineÔÉÅ

class AutoCarver.ContinuousCarver(min_freq: float, *, quantitative_features: list[str] | None = None, qualitative_features: list[str] | None = None, ordinal_features: list[str] | None = None, values_orders: dict[str, AutoCarver.discretizers.utils.grouped_list.GroupedList] | None = None, max_n_mod: int = 5, output_dtype: str = 'float', dropna: bool = True, copy: bool = False, verbose: bool = False, pretty_print: bool = False, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

Automatic carving of continuous, discrete, categorical and ordinal features that maximizes association with a binary or continuous target.

First fits a Discretizer, a complete discretization pipeline. Raw data should be provided as input (not a result of Discretizer.transform()).

Initiates an ContinuousCarver.

Parameters:

  • min_freq (float) ‚Äì

    Minimum frequency per grouped modalities.

    • Features whose most frequent modality is less frequent than min_freq will not be carved.

    • Sets the number of quantiles in which to discretize the continuous features.

    • Sets the minimum frequency of a quantitative feature‚Äôs modality.

    Tip: should be set between 0.02 (slower, preciser, less robust) and 0.05 (faster, more robust)

  • quantitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of quantitative features (continuous and discrete) to be carved, by default None

  • qualitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of qualitative features (non-ordinal) to be carved, by default None

  • ordinal_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of ordinal features to be carved. For those features a list of values has to be provided in the values_orders dict, by default None

  • values_orders (dict[str, GroupedList], optional) ‚Äì Dict of feature‚Äôs column names and there associated ordering. If lists are passed, a GroupedList will automatically be initiated, by default None

  • max_n_mod (int, optional) ‚Äì

    Maximum number of modality per feature, by default 5

    All combinations of modalities for groups of modalities of sizes from 1 to max_n_mod will be tested. The combination with the greatest association (as defined by sort_by) will be the selected one.

    Tip: should be set between 4 (faster, more robust) and 7 (slower, preciser, less robust)

  • output_dtype (str, optional) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["float", "str"], by default "float"

    • "float", grouped modalities will be converted to there corresponding floating rank.

    • "str", a per-group modality will be set for all the modalities of a group.

  • dropna (bool, optional) ‚Äì

    • True, AutoCarver will try to group numpy.nan with other modalities.

    • False, AutoCarver all non-numpy.nan will be grouped, by default True

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, feature processing at transform is applied to a copy of the provided DataFrame, by default False

  • verbose (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, prints raw Discretizers Fit and Transform steps, as long as information on AutoCarver‚Äôs processing and tables of target rates and frequencies for X, by default False

  • pretty_print (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, adds to the verbose some HTML tables of target rates and frequencies for X and, if provided, X_dev. Overrides the value of verbose, by default False

  • **kwargs ‚Äì Pass values for str_default``and ``str_nan of Discretizer (default string values).

Examples

See AutoCarver examples

AutoCarver, the automated, fast-paced data processing pipelineÔÉÅ

class AutoCarver.MulticlassCarver(min_freq: float, sort_by: str, *, quantitative_features: list[str] | None = None, qualitative_features: list[str] | None = None, ordinal_features: list[str] | None = None, values_orders: dict[str, AutoCarver.discretizers.utils.grouped_list.GroupedList] | None = None, max_n_mod: int = 5, output_dtype: str = 'float', dropna: bool = True, copy: bool = False, verbose: bool = False, pretty_print: bool = False, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

Automatic carving of continuous, discrete, categorical and ordinal features that maximizes association with a binary or continuous target.

First fits a Discretizer, a complete discretization pipeline. Raw data should be provided as input (not a result of Discretizer.transform()).

Initiates a MulticlassCarver.

Parameters:

  • min_freq (float) ‚Äì

    Minimum frequency per grouped modalities.

    • Features whose most frequent modality is less frequent than min_freq will not be carved.

    • Sets the number of quantiles in which to discretize the continuous features.

    • Sets the minimum frequency of a quantitative feature‚Äôs modality.

    Tip: should be set between 0.02 (slower, preciser, less robust) and 0.05 (faster, more robust)

  • sort_by (str) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["tschuprowt", "cramerv", "kruskal"] Metric to be used to perform association measure between features and target.

    • Binary target: use "tschuprowt", for Tschuprow‚Äôs T.

    • Binary target: use "cramerv", for Cram√©r‚Äôs V.

    • Continuous target: use "kruskal", for Kruskal-Wallis‚Äô H test statistic.

    Tip: use "tschuprowt" for more robust, or less output modalities, use "cramerv" for more output modalities.

  • quantitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of quantitative features (continuous and discrete) to be carved, by default None

  • qualitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of qualitative features (non-ordinal) to be carved, by default None

  • ordinal_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of ordinal features to be carved. For those features a list of values has to be provided in the values_orders dict, by default None

  • values_orders (dict[str, GroupedList], optional) ‚Äì Dict of feature‚Äôs column names and there associated ordering. If lists are passed, a GroupedList will automatically be initiated, by default None

  • max_n_mod (int, optional) ‚Äì

    Maximum number of modality per feature, by default 5

    All combinations of modalities for groups of modalities of sizes from 1 to max_n_mod will be tested. The combination with the greatest association (as defined by sort_by) will be the selected one.

    Tip: should be set between 4 (faster, more robust) and 7 (slower, preciser, less robust)

  • output_dtype (str, optional) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["float", "str"], by default "float"

    • "float", grouped modalities will be converted to there corresponding floating rank.

    • "str", a per-group modality will be set for all the modalities of a group.

  • dropna (bool, optional) ‚Äì

    • True, AutoCarver will try to group numpy.nan with other modalities.

    • False, AutoCarver all non-numpy.nan will be grouped, by default True

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, feature processing at transform is applied to a copy of the provided DataFrame, by default False

  • verbose (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, prints raw Discretizers Fit and Transform steps, as long as information on AutoCarver‚Äôs processing and tables of target rates and frequencies for X, by default False

  • pretty_print (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, adds to the verbose some HTML tables of target rates and frequencies for X and, if provided, X_dev. Overrides the value of verbose, by default False

  • **kwargs ‚Äì Pass values for str_default``and ``str_nan of Discretizer (default string values).

Examples

See AutoCarver examples

  • y (Series) ‚Äì Multiclass target feature with wich the association is maximized.

Fit to data, then transform it.

Parameters:

  • y (array-like of shape (n_samples,) or (n_samples, n_outputs), default=None) ‚Äì Target values (None for unsupervised transformations).

transform(X: DataFrame, y: Series = None) → DataFrameÔÉÅ

Applies discretization to a DataFrame‚Äôs columns.

  • For each feature‚Äôs modality, the associated group label is attributed as definid by values_orders.

  • If output_dtype="float", converts labels into floats.

  • Data types are matched as input_dtypes=="str" for qualitative features and input_dtypes=="float" for quantitative ones.

  • If copye=True, the input DataFrame will be copied.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) ‚Äì Contains columns named after BaseDiscretizer.features attribute, by default None

  • y (Series, optional) ‚Äì Model target, by default None

Returns:

Discretized X.

Return type:

DataFrame

AutoCarver, the automated, fast-paced data processing pipelineÔÉÅ

class AutoCarver.BaseCarver(min_freq: float, sort_by: str, *, quantitative_features: list[str] | None = None, qualitative_features: list[str] | None = None, ordinal_features: list[str] | None = None, values_orders: dict[str, AutoCarver.discretizers.utils.grouped_list.GroupedList] | None = None, max_n_mod: int = 5, min_freq_mod: float | None = None, output_dtype: str = 'float', dropna: bool = True, copy: bool = False, verbose: bool = False, pretty_print: bool = False, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

Automatic carving of continuous, discrete, categorical and ordinal features that maximizes association with a binary or continuous target.

First fits a Discretizer, a complete discretization pipeline. Raw data should be provided as input (not a result of Discretizer.transform()).

Initiates a BaseCarver.

Parameters:

  • min_freq (float) ‚Äì

    Minimum frequency per grouped modalities.

    • Features whose most frequent modality is less frequent than min_freq will not be carved.

    • Sets the number of quantiles in which to discretize the continuous features.

    • Sets the minimum frequency of a quantitative feature‚Äôs modality.

    Tip: should be set between 0.02 (slower, preciser, less robust) and 0.05 (faster, more robust)

  • sort_by (str) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["tschuprowt", "cramerv", "kruskal"] Metric to be used to perform association measure between features and target.

    • Binary target: use "tschuprowt", for Tschuprow‚Äôs T.

    • Binary target: use "cramerv", for Cram√©r‚Äôs V.

    • Continuous target: use "kruskal", for Kruskal-Wallis‚Äô H test statistic.

    Tip: use "tschuprowt" for more robust, or less output modalities, use "cramerv" for more output modalities.

  • quantitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of quantitative features (continuous and discrete) to be carved, by default None

  • qualitative_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of qualitative features (non-ordinal) to be carved, by default None

  • ordinal_features (list[str], optional) ‚Äì List of column names of ordinal features to be carved. For those features a list of values has to be provided in the values_orders dict, by default None

  • values_orders (dict[str, GroupedList], optional) ‚Äì Dict of feature‚Äôs column names and there associated ordering. If lists are passed, a GroupedList will automatically be initiated, by default None

  • max_n_mod (int, optional) ‚Äì

    Maximum number of modality per feature, by default 5

    All combinations of modalities for groups of modalities of sizes from 1 to max_n_mod will be tested. The combination with the greatest association (as defined by sort_by) will be the selected one.

    Tip: should be set between 4 (faster, more robust) and 7 (slower, preciser, less robust)

  • output_dtype (str, optional) ‚Äì

    To be choosen amongst ["float", "str"], by default "float"

    • "float", grouped modalities will be converted to there corresponding floating rank.

    • "str", a per-group modality will be set for all the modalities of a group.

  • dropna (bool, optional) ‚Äì

    • True, AutoCarver will try to group numpy.nan with other modalities.

    • False, AutoCarver all non-numpy.nan will be grouped, by default True

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, feature processing at transform is applied to a copy of the provided DataFrame, by default False

  • verbose (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, prints raw Discretizers Fit and Transform steps, as long as information on AutoCarver‚Äôs processing and tables of target rates and frequencies for X, by default False

  • pretty_print (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, adds to the verbose some HTML tables of target rates and frequencies for X and, if provided, X_dev. Overrides the value of verbose, by default False

  • **kwargs ‚Äì Pass values for str_default``and ``str_nan of Discretizer (default string values).

  • For each feature‚Äôs modality, the associated group label is attributed as definid by values_orders.

  • If output_dtype="float", converts labels into floats.

  • Data types are matched as input_dtypes=="str" for qualitative features and input_dtypes=="float" for quantitative ones.

AutoCarver saving and loadingÔÉÅ

str

AutoCarver.load_carver(auto_carver_json: dict) → BaseDiscretizerÔÉÅ

Allows one to load an AutoCarver saved as a .json file.

The AutoCarver has to be saved with json.dump(f, AutoCarver.to_json()), otherwise there can be no guarantee for it to be restored.

Parameters:

auto_carver_json (str) ‚Äì Loaded .json file using json.load(f).

Returns:

A fitted AutoCarver.

Return type:

BaseDiscretizer
